title: How long does it take to become a good cyclist? - Quora

response.answer_text: How long does it take to become a strong cyclist? A lifetime. That’s because “strong” is a term we cyclists apply relative to our ambitions. Most of us will ride our entire lives and never have quite to the level of conditioning and ability that we want, to accomplish our cycling goals. (For example, I have long been trying to build the legs and conditioning to ascend Alpe d’hues in sixty minutes; as yet, I’m nowhere near that. On the other hand, I have accomplished my goals of tackling more than one century ride in a season, and “stage” rides of several days.) I believe that even the pros have a similar mindset. For example, I wonder if, last Sunday in Paris, Primoz Roglic would have considered himself a “strong” rider. I wonder if even Tadej Pogacar, looking ahead, would have considered himself a “strong” rider. (Obviously, Lance Armstrong never considered himself a strong rider because he never competed without doping.) Read Peter Sagan’s daily feed during the races, and it’s clear that he does not consider himself “strong” on given days. So “strong” is all relative. That said, there’s clearly an objective standard for strong: The ability to pedal one’s preferred rides in reasonable times for the distances, and completing the rides with a reserve of energy such that we can proceed to the next ride or goal. But to answer the question specifically. Suppose you are an amateur rider— a club rider— in average good health, and some experience riding, it shouldn’t take you more than a season to become strong. Start early and establish a conditioning baseline, then start training for specific goals. For example, Bicycling Magazine has an eight-week plan to train for a century: The 8-Week Training Plan to Ride a Century. Naturally, if you are racing, or aspire to the ranks of the pros, it will take you longer— and more intense training— to become strong. In all, becoming a strong rider really depends on your cycling goals. But the important point is, you can work towards those goals your whole life, and in doing so, enjoy your life on the bike.

That is a “how long is a piece of string?” type question. A good professional cyclist, a good club cyclist or a good recreational cyclist? Which do you aspire to? If you are out of your teens, I’d suggest you forget the Professional. As for club riders, most have age group standards, so you won’t be competing against youngster (although, I find it satisfying beating the times of those half my age). First off you need a bike that fits you and that’s not as easy as some would have you believe. It’s also worth mentioning that not all road bikes are the same. I know they look the same but there are subtle differences that means you might have spent thousands on a bike but you’ll never get it to fit you as well as one by a different manufacturer that’s half the price. Once you have a bike that fits you, you’ll need to put in the hard hours in the saddle. Prepare for a sore rear for many weeks as you slowly increase your time in the saddle and get your rear used to it. NB there is no short-cut. Then find yourself a training plan you can stick to and within a few months you’ll find you are completing routes quicker than when you started. Then you’ll join Strava and realise you are already quicker than others near you. After that it’s a slippery slope, as you push yourself harder to complete sections quicker and work yourself up the leader board. I’d say that when you are in the top half for your age group on Strava, you should call yourself a “good cyclist”.
